pr_title: [Cross Client Batching - 1b] | Wiring TimeLock Batch endpoints

timeline.bodyText: I don't know leader time (and/or the internals of Timelock) all that well - would leader times from different namespaces have different leadership IDs, or the same? If you expect one or the other, can you verify that in this test?
timeline.author: Jolyon-S

replies.bodyText: Leadership ids should be different as each client will have its own instance of AsyncTimelockService -> AsyncLockService -> LeaderClock. I've added the check now.
replies.author: sudiksha27

timeline.bodyText: This is perhaps being a bit pedantic, but get commit timestamps have a leader ID hidden inside (it's the logId inside LockWatchStateUpdate). Perhaps worth a similar check to the one above?
timeline.author: Jolyon-S

timeline.bodyText: maybe a bit overkill: if we run these against the regular conjuretimelockservice.getLeaderTime we get the same answer right?
timeline.author: jeremyk-91

replies.bodyText: Same leader will serve the request, but leaderTime will be different (time elapsed b/w two requests). I will add this test for commitTs request as well, where I can add stricter assertions on the response.
replies.author: sudiksha27

replies.bodyText: Yeah, makes sense. I think I intended an ID comparison, which you've added below.
replies.author: jeremyk-91

timeline.bodyText: nit/suggestion: Usually these assertions are assertThat(actual).isEqualTo(expected), so I'd probably flip these two. Also, you can use as(String) to say in English what the assertion is doing, which I think is useful for this later one, which verifies timestamps are contiguously increasing per namespace if there are no elections.
timeline.author: jeremyk-91
